content.title: Malperfusion Syndromes in Aortic Dissection
content.definition: Organ or limb ischemia resulting from compromised branch vessel perfusion in aortic dissection. Occurs when the dissection flap obstructs branch vessel origins or when the true lumen is severely compressed. Malperfusion is a major determinant of mortality and morbidity in aortic dissection.

static_obstruction.mechanism: Intimal flap extends into branch vessel

dynamic_obstruction.mechanism: True lumen compression, flap prolapses across ostium
dynamic_obstruction.treatment: May respond to proximal therapy alone

coronary.mortality: Very high, especially with cardiogenic shock

mesenteric.presentation: Abdominal pain out of proportion, lactate elevation

renal.diagnosis: CT showing asymmetric perfusion, rising creatinine

management: May resolve with proximal aortic repair

type_a.rationale: Restores true lumen flow, may resolve malperfusion
type_a.exceptions: Severe mesenteric ischemia may require revascularization first

type_b_with_malperfusion.goal: Restore true lumen flow, cover entry tear
techniques: Bare metal stent to expand true lumen

learning_objectives: Recognize the clinical presentations of different malperfusion syndromes
Differentiate static vs dynamic obstruction mechanisms
Apply appropriate treatment strategies for each type
clinical_pearls: Malperfusion is a surgical emergency - don't delay treatment
RCA is more commonly affected than LCA in coronary malperfusion
Mesenteric malperfusion has highest mortality - check lactate
Dynamic obstruction may resolve with central repair; static needs local treatment
Type B dissection with malperfusion = complicated = needs intervention
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Type B dissection is always managed medically - Reality: Malperfusion in Type B requires intervention
